So, I historically, it is true that small caps tend to underperform in pre-election years, not to the extent that we've seen this year, the magnitude, but it's true that pre-election years large caps do tend to outperform small caps. In election years, though, which is what next year is, small caps do tend to outperform large. So, I think from an asset allocation perspective, there is an argument to be made that next year will not be the year of the Magnificent 7, that there will be the year of Smin, small and mid cap. So, it's like, if you're going to play equities, the catch-up trade, which everyone talks about probably does manifest next year. The question becomes the sequence, in other words, does it happen at the start of the year or after some kind of capitulation credit event, which I still think is the more likely near-term scenario? But I think that's probably the real area to kind of pay attention to. It's just that play of the laggards. That's probably going to be the biggest leader. I also think that there will be a lot of demand and money rotating

If the Fed is done, which it seems like they are, and if you get any kind of heightened volatility, you would expect that defensive sectors, which are high dividend paying sectors, utility, stable, and out there, probably get some relative strength as well. So there's two trade-ups, right? There's the defensive sector allocation from large cap-side, utility, stable, healthcare, and then there's the cap rotation from a small cap-side, right, which I think both can work. The thing I'm most confident in, which I could be totally wrong on, is that we're probably not going to see this large cap dominance like we've seen.
